content: Just on tonights news...Drywall used in homes in the United States is from China...yup, China! The drywall emits noxius fumes and causes corrosion to plumbing and electrical wiring. A woman in Florida had to move out of her home, because it was making her sick. Her home sits empty and she still has make payments on it! What does it take for idiots in the States to realize, "DO NOT BUY ANYTHING FROM CHINA" It doesn't take a charter member of Mensa, to figure out, QUIT BUYING CRAP FROM CHINA!!! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: I think the contractors who were building these homes had an obligation to tell the home owners that they got the crap from China. Has it come to this in America that every time we need something built we have to tell them "Nothing from China" or is "everything American made"? The sad fact of the matter is that even with the bad economy we face today, thanks to our own greed, more and more American jobs are being out sourced to places like India, and Mexico. At first it was simply factory jobs and unskilled labor now I hear that IBM has out sourced more than 7000 jobs and most of them are skilled jobs to other countries.

content: My grand daughter was in the Air Force, whe worked as a med tech. Her husband was in the Air Force too, he was a tanker pilot. She convincet her husband to get out of the Air Force,she quit too. They moved back to Evanston WY where her parents live. The only job in town was at Walmart. When Walmart moved in the business down town were closing at a great rate. Her dad made $6.75 an hour, she and her husband made $4.25 an hour. She eventually got back in the AF and her husband got back in the AF too. They are based at Suison Bay CA. Walmart destroyed a small town. I don't DO Walmart, there prices are cheap all made in China. My friend has a Walmart card she invites me to go to Walmart. I say NO all the time.
reply: My grand daughter was in the Air Force, whe worked as a med tech. Her husband was in the Air Force too, he was a tanker pilot. content: I only go to Walmart in a pinch. It takes a concerted effort to shop local and buy American. I think it's the only way we're going to get the country back in balance. How people consume is the real engine of the economy. It does more than all the politicians put together.
reply: I only go to Walmart in a pinch. It takes a concerted effort to shop local and buy American. I think it's the only way we're going to get the country back in balance. How people consume is the real engine of the economy. It does more than all the politicians put together.
title: When Will They Ever Learn!

content: I like to read articles by James Quinn, he seems to have more horse sense and boldness than... well, anybody. Here's some suggestions to ponder from his article "Escalator of Life - Going Down" *http://www.financialsense.com/editorials/quinn/2009/0319.html quote: Bring your lunch to work. Savings of $1,000 to $2,000 per year. Buy 2 lbs of Maxwell House coffee for $6 at Wal-Mart and make a pot of coffee per day for a month rather than buying a $4 cup at Starbucks and save $1,000 per year. Stop buying things. Keep your appliances until they stop working. Realize that it isn’t a competition with your neighbor to die with the most stuff. Mow your own lawn. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Learn to embrace dandelions and crabgrass. Who cares? Wash your car in the driveway. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Buy your next car and drive it for 10 years or 150,000 miles, whichever comes first. Buy a car that gets at least 30 mpg, as $200 a barrel oil is a certainty in the next decade. Tell your kids they are lucky to have whatever you give them. When you walk into a room and CNBC is on TV, switch immediately to When Animals Attack. Don’t answer the phone – it’s someone asking for something. Don’t throw out your old sneakers – you can use them to cut the lawn. Turn the heat down to 60 degrees at night. Go to the poor man’s Disney World, Wildwood, N.J. and save $4,000 for a weeks vacation. Eat out once per month rather than three times a week and you’ll magically save $3,000 to $4,000 per year. Contribute into your 401k until it hurts. Picture yourself handing out yellow smiley stickers at the age of 80 in a Wal-Mart as motivation. Buy some gold, just in case. Plant a vegetable garden, just in case. Instead of spending $40 at the movies, go for a hike in a National Park like Valley Forge. Have a catch with your son. Understand the motivation of anyone who is telling you anything. Most people have an angle. When the guy in the Mercedes or BMW in front of you is wearing their hat sideways, your taxes are probably making their car loan payment. When you see that same guy pushing a cart with a 52 inch HDTV out of Best Buy, your taxes are probably making the payment to Capital One.
quote: Bring your lunch to work. Savings of $1,000 to $2,000 per year. Buy 2 lbs of Maxwell House coffee for $6 at Wal-Mart and make a pot of coffee per day for a month rather than buying a $4 cup at Starbucks and save $1,000 per year. Stop buying things. Keep your appliances until they stop working. Realize that it isn’t a competition with your neighbor to die with the most stuff. Mow your own lawn. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Learn to embrace dandelions and crabgrass. Who cares? Wash your car in the driveway. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Buy your next car and drive it for 10 years or 150,000 miles, whichever comes first. Buy a car that gets at least 30 mpg, as $200 a barrel oil is a certainty in the next decade. Tell your kids they are lucky to have whatever you give them. When you walk into a room and CNBC is on TV, switch immediately to When Animals Attack. Don’t answer the phone – it’s someone asking for something. Don’t throw out your old sneakers – you can use them to cut the lawn. Turn the heat down to 60 degrees at night. Go to the poor man’s Disney World, Wildwood, N.J. and save $4,000 for a weeks vacation. Eat out once per month rather than three times a week and you’ll magically save $3,000 to $4,000 per year. Contribute into your 401k until it hurts. Picture yourself handing out yellow smiley stickers at the age of 80 in a Wal-Mart as motivation. Buy some gold, just in case. Plant a vegetable garden, just in case. Instead of spending $40 at the movies, go for a hike in a National Park like Valley Forge. Have a catch with your son. Understand the motivation of anyone who is telling you anything. Most people have an angle. When the guy in the Mercedes or BMW in front of you is wearing their hat sideways, your taxes are probably making their car loan payment. When you see that same guy pushing a cart with a 52 inch HDTV out of Best Buy, your taxes are probably making the payment to Capital One.
reply: I like to read articles by James Quinn, he seems to have more horse sense and boldness than... well, anybody. Here's some suggestions to ponder from his article "Escalator of Life - Going Down" *http://www.financialsense.com/editorials/quinn/2009/0319.html

content: My grand daughter was in the Air Force, whe worked as a med tech. Her husband was in the Air Force too, he was a tanker pilot. She convincet her husband to get out of the Air Force,she quit too. They moved back to Evanston WY where her parents live. The only job in town was at Walmart. When Walmart moved in the business down town were closing at a great rate. Her dad made $6.75 an hour, she and her husband made $4.25 an hour. She eventually got back in the AF and her husband got back in the AF too. They are based at Suison Bay CA. Walmart destroyed a small town. I don't DO Walmart, there prices are cheap all made in China. My friend has a Walmart card she invites me to go to Walmart. I say NO all the time.

title: When Will They Ever Learn!

content: I only go to Walmart in a pinch. It takes a concerted effort to shop local and buy American. I think it's the only way we're going to get the country back in balance. How people consume is the real engine of the economy. It does more than all the politicians put together.
reply: I only go to Walmart in a pinch. It takes a concerted effort to shop local and buy American. I think it's the only way we're going to get the country back in balance. How people consume is the real engine of the economy. It does more than all the politicians put together.
title: When Will They Ever Learn!

content: I like to read articles by James Quinn, he seems to have more horse sense and boldness than... well, anybody. Here's some suggestions to ponder from his article "Escalator of Life - Going Down" *http://www.financialsense.com/editorials/quinn/2009/0319.html quote: Bring your lunch to work. Savings of $1,000 to $2,000 per year. Buy 2 lbs of Maxwell House coffee for $6 at Wal-Mart and make a pot of coffee per day for a month rather than buying a $4 cup at Starbucks and save $1,000 per year. Stop buying things. Keep your appliances until they stop working. Realize that it isn’t a competition with your neighbor to die with the most stuff. Mow your own lawn. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Learn to embrace dandelions and crabgrass. Who cares? Wash your car in the driveway. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Buy your next car and drive it for 10 years or 150,000 miles, whichever comes first. Buy a car that gets at least 30 mpg, as $200 a barrel oil is a certainty in the next decade. Tell your kids they are lucky to have whatever you give them. When you walk into a room and CNBC is on TV, switch immediately to When Animals Attack. Don’t answer the phone – it’s someone asking for something. Don’t throw out your old sneakers – you can use them to cut the lawn. Turn the heat down to 60 degrees at night. Go to the poor man’s Disney World, Wildwood, N.J. and save $4,000 for a weeks vacation. Eat out once per month rather than three times a week and you’ll magically save $3,000 to $4,000 per year. Contribute into your 401k until it hurts. Picture yourself handing out yellow smiley stickers at the age of 80 in a Wal-Mart as motivation. Buy some gold, just in case. Plant a vegetable garden, just in case. Instead of spending $40 at the movies, go for a hike in a National Park like Valley Forge. Have a catch with your son. Understand the motivation of anyone who is telling you anything. Most people have an angle. When the guy in the Mercedes or BMW in front of you is wearing their hat sideways, your taxes are probably making their car loan payment. When you see that same guy pushing a cart with a 52 inch HDTV out of Best Buy, your taxes are probably making the payment to Capital One.
quote: Bring your lunch to work. Savings of $1,000 to $2,000 per year. Buy 2 lbs of Maxwell House coffee for $6 at Wal-Mart and make a pot of coffee per day for a month rather than buying a $4 cup at Starbucks and save $1,000 per year. Stop buying things. Keep your appliances until they stop working. Realize that it isn’t a competition with your neighbor to die with the most stuff. Mow your own lawn. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Learn to embrace dandelions and crabgrass. Who cares? Wash your car in the driveway. Better yet, if you have kids, make them do it. Buy your next car and drive it for 10 years or 150,000 miles, whichever comes first. Buy a car that gets at least 30 mpg, as $200 a barrel oil is a certainty in the next decade. Tell your kids they are lucky to have whatever you give them. When you walk into a room and CNBC is on TV, switch immediately to When Animals Attack. Don’t answer the phone – it’s someone asking for something. Don’t throw out your old sneakers – you can use them to cut the lawn. Turn the heat down to 60 degrees at night. Go to the poor man’s Disney World, Wildwood, N.J. and save $4,000 for a weeks vacation. Eat out once per month rather than three times a week and you’ll magically save $3,000 to $4,000 per year. Contribute into your 401k until it hurts. Picture yourself handing out yellow smiley stickers at the age of 80 in a Wal-Mart as motivation. Buy some gold, just in case. Plant a vegetable garden, just in case. Instead of spending $40 at the movies, go for a hike in a National Park like Valley Forge. Have a catch with your son. Understand the motivation of anyone who is telling you anything. Most people have an angle. When the guy in the Mercedes or BMW in front of you is wearing their hat sideways, your taxes are probably making their car loan payment. When you see that same guy pushing a cart with a 52 inch HDTV out of Best Buy, your taxes are probably making the payment to Capital One.
reply: I like to read articles by James Quinn, he seems to have more horse sense and boldness than... well, anybody. Here's some suggestions to ponder from his article "Escalator of Life - Going Down" *http://www.financialsense.com/editorials/quinn/2009/0319.html
title: When Will They Ever Learn!

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: Just on tonights news...Drywall used in homes in the United States is from China...yup, China! The drywall emits noxius fumes and causes corrosion to plumbing and electrical wiring. A woman in Florida had to move out of her home, because it was making her sick. Her home sits empty and she still has make payments on it! What does it take for idiots in the States to realize, "DO NOT BUY ANYTHING FROM CHINA" It doesn't take a charter member of Mensa, to figure out, QUIT BUYING CRAP FROM CHINA!!! I guess I should dump my Wal-Mart stock then.

content: Are Target or K-mart any different?? I don't shop much (at all) if I can help it. I just know about everything I've bought over the past ten years, even through sportsmansguide, is made in the orient... Americans won't put their hands to a gear driven machine anymore unless it's... ... BMW!! Wandering and Wondering
